title: Grow More Give More: Planting a Raised Bed Garden

tasks.task: Setting up and planting a raised bed garden.
subtasks: Familiarizing with planting techniques for raised bed gardens.
Understanding block planting design for raised beds.
Learning proper spacing for different crops (24 inches for large crops, 1 foot for smaller ones, 18 inches for cabbage, broccoli, pepper, etc., 2 feet for tomatoes, squash, etc.).
Applying planting techniques to optimize space.
Identifying appropriate spacing for different vegetables (determining centers based on vegetable type).
Properly spacing plants within 1-foot squares (e.g., 32 plants per square for corn, lettuces, Irish potatoes, okra).
Using blot or dense planting techniques to maximize space efficiency.
Ensuring proper spacing for large and smaller vegetables (e.g., 18 inches for cabbage, 6 inches for beans, onions, carrots, and radishes).

tasks.task: Adapting traditional planting methods for raised beds.
subtasks: Realizing the difference between traditional row gardening and raised bed gardening.
Understanding the importance of not wasting space in raised beds.
Adjusting plant spacing accordingly to optimize raised bed garden's productivity.

tasks.task: Planting a raised bed garden using block spacing.
Planting a raised bed garden with correct spacing.
Planting a raised bed garden following best practices.
Planting a raised bed garden using block spacing.
Planting a raised bed garden following the Outer Carpet Extension System's block planting method.
Planting a raised bed garden with proper spacing, arranged in a block design rather than rows.
Planting a raised bed garden using optimized block spacing.
MAINTASK: Planting a raised bed garden using block spacing.
subtasks: Familiarizing with the block planting design compared to traditional row gardening.

Applying spacing guidelines for different crops: 24 inches for large crops (tomatoes, squash), 12-18 inches for medium-sized crops (cabbage, potatoes, corn), and 4-6 inches for small crops (beans, peas, onions).
Ensuring proper placement of plants to maximize space in a one-foot square design, such as fitting 32 small plants per square foot or appropriate spacing for larger plants, ensuring no wasted space.
